Clearly, this is an important area, one that is addressing issues of a national approach to our transport system.

I was reminded this morning that we have a long way to go in our banking system as far as our state entities are concerned. I went to transfer a reasonably substantial sum this morning from my bank here in Canberra to my bank in Western Australia and the bank wanted an $80 tax for the privilege. I might add that I did not transfer the money. Apparently, that is not a bank charge; that is a charge imposed by the ACT authorities to allow me to send money through a computer, which is probably based in Melbourne, to Western Australia. It is damn silly. However, here we are trying to resolve some of those problems. We also have an example here of how the major parties can get together to address serious national issues, and that is what this chamber is all about.

Unfortunately, you are not going to see issues of native title in this chamber. You are not going to see issues of uniform reform of the tax system here either because our opponents have a feral approach to that which says that the political advantage outweighs the national interest. They are not issues that need to be confrontational. They are issues where the major parties, because of the extreme national importance of the issues, should be running around saying, `What is reasonable? What is fair to the people? What are the offsets that certain sections of the community might need, say, in the tax system if you made major changes?'

We should be able to stand up in this building, be it in the main chamber or in this chamber, and address the national interest rather than party political interests. Okay, I think there are plenty of opportunities to present yourself as better administrators, as better able to run the country, but we should not be using matters of extreme national importance for the purpose of trying to improve our own political chances. Unfortunately, that is happening. For example, look at the issue of work for the dole. There has to be a national benefit. The two parties should not be sparring over the issue. They should be getting together to say, `What is the best way to implement such a process? What is fair? What is reasonable?'

There is a message to the media in all of that but, of course, the media do not listen to what goes on in this chamber for the simple reason that there is no confrontation. In fact, 90 per cent of them, if they were asked to attend in this place, could not find it. That is a great pity because the national interest is being addressed in this chamber. I just make that point because it is the chamber in which people do get together to progress the national interest.

Having said that, it is also a place where members such as me, with no influence at cabinet level, can make comments on this sort of legislation in the hope that people—and I welcome those who are here today—who have a huge influence on the administration of these things can take them into account. I want to make points that are not necessarily against the proposals in the legislation but I want to raise issues that should be considered as time goes by.

My background in business included both directorship and ownership of quite large road vehicles in Western Australia. I lived in Carnarvon where road transport was eventually its only source of transport. We did have shipping at one stage but that became so inefficient through bad work practices that over a 600‐mile journey it could not compete with trucks that, initially, were travelling over 300 miles of unsealed road. You would not believe that that could be the case but, in fact, it was.

I can well remember on one occasion deciding that I wanted to support the local shipping service. I was a substantial importer of goods to the town as a hotel proprietor, so I thought I would give the shipping company a bit of work. The only problem was that the goods arrived three days late and left me in an embarrassing situation in supplying my customers, and some of the goods arrived in damaged condition. It was just plain stupid that I should try and share my freight bill amongst the wharfies, the seamen and the trucking operators. That gives you some idea of why that was so.

We discovered that, even under a road transport regime with government involvement, it was a franchise. We were told that if we had a monopoly it would be cheaper. We eventually discovered and believed that the monopoly was not serving us properly and I, amongst other citizens, formed a cooperative transport company to compete for our own work, and we did so by tendering to the government, notwithstanding that the government officials told us there was no way that we could reduce the price of freight into Carnarvon. They used the words, `We've gone through their figures, Mr Tuckey, with a fine toothcomb.'

We underbid the franchised operator by 30 per cent. I might add that it took something like 12 years before the prices we charged the community—and I want to underline that word `community'—reached the bid price of our then competitor. In all that time, the cooperative made good profits—which, by the way, it returned to its customers. It was an interesting situation to support the argument for competition. I might add that, having won the monopoly, we invited our competitor back into the business to keep us honest. We then had a duopoly, but we retained 90 per cent of the business and they had 10 per cent. They were a very substantial organisation, well known throughout Australia today. The realities are that that provides another aspect of all the matters of road transport; but I put that up on the basis of my credentials.

During that period, it was my personal advocacy with the then state minister for transport, Mr Ray O'Connor, that got the extension of road trains—which were limited originally from Carnarvon to Geraldton—through to the outskirts of Perth. I want to comment on the developments in that area. That represented huge financial savings. Of course, because we were transporting perishables and it was simply impossible to break up a road train 300 miles from destination with perishable goods, Mr O'Connor agreed to a trial for six months of two or three of our vehicles to prove the point. In six weeks he opened the road up to anyone, because we proved beyond doubt that these vehicles did not represent a threat to the safety of the community—and, of course, that has been established even further.

This legislation is about setting national parameters for vehicle registration and vehicle configuration. It is on the issue of vehicle configuration that I want to address this particular committee, because that has been one of the greatest areas of stupidity on a state by state basis. Clearly, as you add to the load carrying capacity of a single prime mover by adding additional trailers, there is a substantial opportunity to reduce freight costs. The big cost is in the prime mover and, of course, in the operator. Even fuel consumption is not relative to doubling the load of a road train or to the creation of a B‐double or any of those other configurations.

The interesting point was that, quite clearly, certain states—Victoria, in particular—for decades used the road registration system as a non‐tariff barrier to protect the railways, which were encouraged into gross inefficiencies as a consequence. Who paid for that? Consumers. It is a reality, for a number of reasons, that trucks are more efficient than rail. Rail dominates when it gets to very large bulk loads over substantial distances. I have pointed out in my own electorate over the years that, whilst people like rail and they say it gets trucks off the road and does all sorts of things, the load that is shifted throughout my electorate each year, where there is about 4,000 kilometres of track, is 1,175 tonnes of freight per kilometre of infrastructure.

The iron ore province in Western Australia shifts 80,000 tonnes of product per annum per kilometre of rail infrastructure. They also have too many kilometres of rail. As the late Lang Hancock pointed out, initially they should have had a central line with spurs. There is one available that is downhill all the way. An electric train running on it would generate electricity for the entire trip. However, the realities are that, even there, there are inefficiencies because of the system. Those inefficiencies should have been addressed in the initial planning stages of that wonderful asset of Australian resources.

My point is that I still have fears about having a national system. Western Australia and, very closely, Queensland set the pattern in the use of efficient truck configurations. They proved that they were not a danger. The Court government—and the Minister for Transport, Eric Charlton—decided to overcome the last stupid barrier to larger configurations. That stupid barrier was that you could not move a road train—that is, two semitrailers, with one towed by the other—in the metropolitan areas. We are still forcing the break‐up on the perimeter of the metropolitan area—it has progressed a long way from my original 300 miles.

The realities were that, when we had that break‐up situation, a third of the revenue of that second trailer was lost in the last 20 or 30 kilometres, because that was the cost involved in having someone else pick it up and bring it in. Quite properly, the Court government said, `This can cease. We will have a trial to prove that these things can run into the saleyards with stock or to the markets with perishables, and so on.'

The shires associated with those last 20 kilometres formed committees, went berserk and carried on, but eventually the trial was considered a success after 500 movements. When I was driving along in my car, a woman who was one of the leaders of the opposition to this rang up and protested vigorously that the minister had decided to open up that section of the road because he believed the trial was a success. Her complaint was that none of the members of her committee had seen one of these trucks on the road. That is how much of a danger they represented—they had never even seen one.

She said, `We really need to have a look at them.' Why had she not seen them? She had not seen them because she had not noticed them. They were there all right. That is when the community gets silly. They are paying the price. I do not mind paying the price for genuine safety and genuine protection of the community, but I do when there is no good reason.

People talk about these larger configurations damaging the roads. If they get off the shoulder because road authorities have made the roads too narrow, naturally the longer vehicles will break a little bit more off the edge. However, when it comes to axle loading, because the weight is in the prime mover, the overall freight per axle loading is less. The best way to put it is that there can be more freight with less weight on the road. It is the aggregate of the axle loading. How can that be doing more damage to the road? However, there are problems with bridges and things like that which are more significant.

I am addressing these issues to make the point that, now we have a uniform system, we should not let it become the lowest common denominator. With the town of Carnarvon, practically for as long as I can remember, three trailers went north. They still only allow two into the town. I am not sure that, with proper and decent roads, that is even a necessity. But every time a trailer is added to an appropriate prime mover a huge decision is being made. This legislation actually puts legislation together for the ACT, but as a model for the states. Section 3 states:
(1) The purpose of this Act is to make provision for the registration of heavy vehicles and for related matters in the Australian Capital Territory and the Jervis Bay Territory.
(2) It is intended—
this is the penultimate fact—
that:
(a) the States and the Northern Territory will:

TAB.TAB: (i) adopt section 2, Division 1 of Part 2, and Parts 3 and 4, as in force from time to time; and
(ii) adopt the regulations as in force from time to time;

SPEECH.PARA: I will take the few minutes I have left to talk about those regulations. Regulations, of course, are the laws that are written after we parliamentarians have passed the law. I believe that in greenfields legislation the regulations should be made available with the law and that we should have some time to give them scrutiny. That does not happen, but it will be the sharp end of an act of this nature. I hope we do not see public pressure and other stupid activities generating this lower common denominator.

New South Wales decided to prevent trucking by charging ridiculously high registration fees and, of course, all their truck owners went off to South Australia. Others said that was dreadful; I said that it serves them right. The realities are that if we overtax road transport, in excess of what is reasonable, then the consumer pays.

At the moment, in terms of the tax debate, this typical semitrailer on full‐time line haul is paying $2,000 a week in taxes. That is if you annualise the original sales tax on the prime mover and the other equipment and take into account fuel taxes and all of these things. That, to me, is patently silly in a country like Australia where we have huge distances involved.

In elections I used to make the point that if previous Prime Minister Keating had been dragged off to Russia by the KGB in his youth to be brainwashed into wrecking the Australian economy—as you and I now know, such a trip was not necessary—the first thing they would have taught him to do is tax transport. They would have said, `Tax transport. The higher you tax transport, the quicker you can wreck the economy.' I have heard statements that Australians' expenditure on transport is as high as $1 in $7 when you measure it through all the times that goods move from A to B.

That is a significant factor we will never overcome because Australia is Australia. Our resources just do not all happen to be within a couple of kilometres of a convenient port. We should look very closely at whether that is an appropriate source of taxation. I say that it is not. I think it is one of the issues that a proper review of the tax system should address.

All of these things are highlighted. Now that we have some centralised legislation, that is fine. I agree that we should not have the silly sorts of situations that existed at one stage where you could head across to South Australia from Western Australia and when you got there they would not let you drive your truck unless you had had their vehicle inspection.

These are all the reasons we are moving towards uniformity. I think that is fine but, as I say, there have been some most unimaginative and economically irresponsible road transport rules that had nothing to do with protecting people on the road, protecting the roads or anything else. In other states it did not happen. All the evidence was that the problems did not arise. We are now driving road trains through the metropolitan area in Perth and people cannot find them, those that bitterly wanted to find them and point out that they had just run over someone. It is ridiculous. They do not represent a danger. In fact, they are very hard to identify amongst all the other traffic.

I think many truck drivers would tell you that the real dangers on the road are not them; they are people towing caravans and people who drive in a highly irresponsible way, particularly in relation to trucks. They see the length of a motor car in front of a truck, that the truck driver has left there for the purpose of not running into the car in front of him, and they pull into the gap and wonder why there is smoke rising off the bitumen. I think there are more dangers there.

These particular dangers should not be taken into account when they do not exist. That was one of the great areas of concern in Western Australia. The first was that we have in some cases had to actually raise our registration fees because the state of Western Australia did not believe it was appropriate to tax people through registration fees. They were there for the purpose of registering the vehicle. Of course, we have had to raise them somewhat but, more importantly, we eventually won the argument.

I think we have some special rights to license larger configurations which are significant to the economy of Western Australia, with the distances involved. I make a plea on the record that at no stage should we use uniformity to get the lowest common denominator. We should always be trying to progress the boundaries, provided we take genuine note of safety for the community and the normal protection of roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey, Fran, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in support of the legislation currently before us, the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 and the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996. These bills comprise two modules of the new national road transport law which is currently being formulated by the National Road Transport Commission, in conjunction with the federal government, state and territory governments and, most importantly, the transport industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Once implemented in their entirety, these new national laws for heavy vehicles will replace almost a century of regulations which, today, are largely antiquated, inefficient and inadequate. The two bills currently before us are an important step towards nationally uniform road transport laws. The Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill establishes a legislative framework for a national regulatory scheme for the transport of dangerous goods by road. These minor amendments will pave the way for the completion of the new national dangerous goods regulations and a revised version of the Australian code for the transport of dangerous goods by road.

The reforms to the dangerous goods laws are designed chiefly to improve the safe transport of dangerous goods by road, enhance national uniformity, and improve enforcement and compliance. The proposed regulations will clarify the responsibilities of each of the parties involved in the transport of dangerous goods, introduce a nationally coordinated administrative system for exemptions, approvals and other decisions, establish a national licensing scheme for vehicles carrying dangerous goods in bulk, and their drivers, and an obligation to use only people who are trained to work with dangerous goods for tasks such as packing, consigning and maintaining equipment.

The Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill establishes a framework for a national registration scheme for heavy vehicles throughout Australia. The scheme will provide uniform arrangements for initial registration, renewal, transfer, suspension and cancellation of registration, and the issue and clearance of vehicle defect notices. Uniform and consistent heavy vehicle registration procedures will end the various different registration requirements across Australia which are confusing, complex and costly to the transport industry.

Australia's road transport industry is among the best in the world. Trucking accounts for about 75 per cent of the Australian freight market in terms of both value and tonnage. Approximately $60 billion of freight is shifted by road transport each year throughout Australia. In 1992‐93, the transport industry contributed 2.9 per cent to Australia's gross domestic product, a figure which continues to rise.

The value of the road transport industry, as an employer, is also significant. Between 1985 and 1993, the industry grew by 21 per cent, which equals 22,800 jobs. Currently, the trucking industry accounts for 1.7 per cent of all employment in Australia. I hasten to add that a large of percentage of that is located in regional Australia.

The trucking industry plays a pivotal role, particularly in my electorate of McEwen. Two of Victoria's main highways dissect McEwen—the Goulburn Valley Highway, which provides a link between Melbourne and Brisbane, and the Hume Highway which is the chief route for transport travelling between Melbourne and Sydney. Without an efficient and cost‐effective road transport system, numerous other industries would collapse. Wineries, farms, manufacturing, retail, timber and mining are just a few of the important industries in my electorate of McEwen which rely on heavy vehicles to conduct their business.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension, I was at a very crucial part of my address in this chamber regarding these two national transport bills. I was on the point of referring to the importance of the trucking industry and how, in our everyday lives, we sometimes do not realise how important it is. I was also about to give some examples.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not realise when we go into the supermarket that the shelves there would not be stocked unless we had an efficient transport industry. We take so many other things for granted as well. For example, service stations would run out of fuel, there would be no means to transport the timber to the sawmills, dairy farmers could not get their milk delivered to the dairies, and wineries—a very big growth industry in the important electorate of McEwen—could not transport their products to their outlets.

Without the transport industry, the very fabric of our society would disintegrate and we simply would not survive. The bus and coach industry is equally important. Not only does it play a vital role in Australia's burgeoning tourism industry, but it also contributes substantially to the national economy and to the social and recreational life of all Australians. Almost a third of the entire Australian passenger market is serviced by the coach and bus industry, which employs 20,000 people. That is why it is essential that our road transport laws are reformed.

In the December 1996 edition of Reformer, the National Road Transport Commission referred to an independent report which estimated that implementation of the entire package of national reforms to road transport could benefit the economy by up to $1 billion a year. The direct economic benefits to the road transport industry and its users are estimated at nearly $500 million a year, or a 13 per cent improvement in overall productivity. And that means jobs and increased economic activity throughout regional Australia.
The report was based on surveys of transport operators from across Australia. The Reformer, in its article, goes on to state:

Most operators said that the reforms would allow them to reduce the size of their fleets, cutting operating costs significantly. Operators said that the reforms would enable them to hold their rates at current levels or reduce them, with most of the benefits being passed to customers and ultimately to consumers via the supply chain.

The Howard government has already clearly shown its commitment to road transport reform, and the development of a uniform national regulatory framework, through the National Road Transport Commission process. While the states and territories and the transport industry have agreed that uniform laws are necessary, there is still some way to go before consensus is reached on all aspects of the national road transport law.

The removal of individual state and territory restrictions and registration charges for heavy vehicles, and the adoption and implementation of nationally uniform rules and standards, will help to reduce costs to both the transport industry and the businesses they supply—and, ultimately, consumers—and will bring about greater efficiencies and competition for truck and bus drivers and operators and lead to a safer transport industry.

BREAK.PARA: It is important to note that these reforms will benefit not only the road transport industry itself but also ultimately each and every Australian through lower costs and charges and safer roads for all road users. As drivers, most of us know that, when travelling along our national roads and even our local roads, trucks and buses can be fairly imposing at times. Living in Victoria's scenic Yarra Valley, with its narrow, winding and hilly roads, I must admit to the occasional bout of nerves when confronted by a heavy vehicle coming around a narrow bend. These fears can be somewhat lessened through road transport law reforms. If we know that heavy vehicles are designed and constructed to be safe and are not defective, and if we know that bus and truck drivers are qualified, experienced, properly licensed and driving responsibly, we can be reassured that we can share the road with them safely.

The safety performance of trucks has improved greatly in the 1990s. Figures from the Federal Office of Road Safety show that last year there were 140 fatal crashes involving articulated trucks in Australia, a 15.2 per cent drop from 1995. This is also a substantial improvement on 1988 when there were 260 fatal crashes recorded. Unfortunately, the number of fatal crashes involving buses increased by 40.9 per cent last year, with 31 fatal crashes in 1996 compared with 22 in 1995. But overall, the heavy vehicle industry itself has a good road safety record. A 1996 Federal Office of Road Safety report on heavy vehicle accidents in urban areas showed that, in two‐thirds of cases, the party at fault was the other road user, not the bus or truck driver. This shows how important it is that motorists drive carefully and sensibly around trucks and buses and remember their manoeuvrability, stopping, turning and acceleration restrictions.

Road accidents, whether or not trucks and buses are involved, come at an enormous cost to all Australians in terms of the number of lives lost and the serious injuries and trauma they cause. Last year a total of 1,973 people lost their lives on our roads—a drop, I must add, of 2.2 per cent on the previous year. Victims of motor vehicle accidents, and their families, experience great physical, psychological and emotional pain, shock and suffering after being involved in crashes, while the community must bear the cost of the $6.1 billion annual road fatality and accident bill. The Federal Office of Road Safety calculates that, for every road death, 15 other people suffer life‐altering injuries.

According to a VicRoads forward strategy entitled National Roads in Victoria, national highways account for 13 per cent of all serious injury accidents on Victorian rural roads, even though national highways represent only one per cent of the rural road length. Between 1990 and 1994, there were 722 serious casualty accidents on national highways in Victoria and, since 1991, the number of serious injury accidents on national highways has increased by 40 per cent.

The federal government has already announced numerous programs specifically aimed at reducing the road toll and increasing road safety. One of the most important initiatives is undoubtedly the reintroduction of the federal road safety black spot funding program which was scrapped by the previous Labour government in 1993.

Before the last election the coalition vowed to restore the black spot program in an effort to reduce road trauma. The government will provide almost $149 million over the next four years towards the program, which will target road locations with a high accident record and where the highest benefits can be achieved. An evaluation of the former federal accident black spot program indicated a return of $4 for every $1 invested. The Federal Office of Road Safety has estimated that one life is saved every year for every $500,000 spent on the black spot program.

The best aspect of this important road safety program is that it involves local communities helping the government to identify and fix Australia's most dangerous roads. Community groups, service clubs and organisations representing motorists and the transport industry are able to nominate dangerous sites for treatment.

There are many such black spots in my electorate of McEwen which require immediate attention, particularly sections along the Goulburn Valley Highway, Maroondah Highway, Main Whittlesea Road and Whittlesea‐Yea Road. These roads have recorded a high level of casualty accidents in recent years mainly due to roadside obstacles and lack of shoulder sealing.

One local council in my electorate, the city of Whittlesea, has already taken advantage of the consultative phase of the black spot program and has nominated three sites in the McEwen electorate for black spot funding. These nominations have been forwarded to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) for his consideration.

As mentioned previously, there are two major highways in my electorate of McEwen which form part of the national highway network—the Hume Highway and the Goulburn Valley Highway north of Seymour. Although these two highways represent only a very small part of the total national highway network, they are of national importance to the road transport system. According to Vicroads, Victoria accounts for 35 per cent of the interstate road freight task and has a 20 per cent share of national road travel. The Goulburn Valley Highway and Hume Freeway also provide a vital link for businesses and primary producers to the port of Melbourne, which handles more than one‐third of the nation's exports and imports and 44 per cent of containers which move through capital city ports.

The Goulburn Valley Highway has become notorious in the past two years for road fatalities and is now referred to by locals as `Hell Highway'. In the 12 months to September 1995, the short stretch of the Goulburn Valley Highway which runs from Seymour to north of Murchison East claimed nine lives in six separate crashes. Heavy vehicles were involved in half of those crashes. The Goulburn Valley Highway is used extensively by the road transport industry carrying freight to the port of Melbourne and interstate. The VicRoads1993 Goulburn Valley Highway strategy estimates that in 1990 about 1.3 million tonnes of freight was transported north of the state border with a similar amount brought south.

There is an urgent need to improve road safety and capacity along the Goulburn Valley Highway by way of progressive duplication and the provision of overtaking lanes. VicRoads believes that upgrading the road would reduce costs of interstate freight movement between Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland and improve the competitiveness of the local region's fruit export industry.

Another section of national highway which is used predominantly for freight transport and which needs attention is the link between the Hume Freeway at Craigieburn and the Western Ring Road. According to Vicroads, there have been 293 casualty accidents, including 11 fatal accidents, along this section of highway over the past five years. It is suggested that a new freeway standard connection is needed between these two points to overcome the high costs of delays and accidents which are currently being experienced. The primary causes are the lack of access control between the existing highway and abutting industrial and commercial development, and the heavy traffic volumes at major signalled intersections.

These two national highways are vital to the road transport industry and we must ensure that they are continually upgraded and improved to meet growing transport requirements and reduce road trauma and its high cost to the Australian community. The road transport industry plays an integral role in the economies of almost every single community in my electorate of McEwen, as it does in the nation as a whole. The government has shown through its road safety and improvement programs, its role in the development of a national road transport law, and the introduction of these two bills before the House today, that it is committed to improving the efficiencies of the road transport industry. This will boost growth, create jobs, cut costs and increase competitiveness, which means massive benefits for the heavy vehicle industry and, in turn, for each and every Australian including, most importantly, those people within the electorate of McEwen. I commend these bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perhaps little known that our economy is completely dependent upon roads for freight transport. Some 75 per cent of the goods moved around Australia each day go by road. Nearly 20 per cent of the cost of goods that we buy in our daily life is attributable to the cost of transport. So it could be said that it is a major part of our economy. Road transport is a $60,000 million per year industry. It is unquestionably a critical player in our domestic economic make‐up, and perhaps it goes a little unnoticed.

SPEECH.PARA: Road transport is of critical importance in the movement of goods, and of critical importance in the cost imposts to both local primary producers, the beef and coal industries, in my electorate—industries whose plight these days is not looking much better. The industry is of critical importance as an employer in regional communities such as Gloucester, Bulahdelah, Stroud and Raymond Terrace. It has been of focal critical importance in matters of national road safety over the past decade or so.

Today I want to focus on some of the big reforms for the industry which map out the direction in which road transport is heading. The objective of these reforms, as far as I am concerned, is to ensure that road transport is in even better shape to improve and grow and, freed from unnecessary government red tape, to secure for those who work in the industry—employer and employee alike—a rewarding future based on professionalism and service to clients.

The best way to achieve this future is for the government and the industry to work hand in hand in partnership, and that is what the Howard government is firmly committed to. The government is committed to securing a better future for all Australians. We have come a long way since the federal government first became involved in road funding back in the 1920s; and, over the next 10 years, we will go a lot further. By the year 2005 or 2006, under a coalition government, I anticipate that we will achieve some major national milestones. Indeed, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, John Sharp, is to be heartily congratulated.

Some examples of reforms are that all the narrow seals on the national highways in rural Australia will have been eliminated, and most of the rural network will have been opened up to unimpeded access to B‐doubles and B‐triples—one of the major forms of transportation in my electorate, as I said before, for beef and for coal. We will see the Summerland Way reconstructed to take freight vehicles off the Pacific Highway and avoid the densely populated areas. I do not think there are too many people who like to see large numbers of trucks, particularly when they are heavily laden B‐doubles, coming past their own front door.

BREAK.PARA: Most importantly for my electorate, we will see the upgrading of the Pacific Highway. In particular, one stretch, the Bulahdelah to Coolongolook deviation, will eliminate the greatest black spots on the eastern seaboard on Highway 1. This is all part of the four‐lane road going all the way from Ballarat to Brisbane through Melbourne and Sydney, and the Pacific Highway is obviously the vital link.

There is in my electorate a further commitment to the section from Coolongolook to Possums Brush of $93 million, which will eliminate another poor stretch of road. All up, the government has given a genuine commitment of some $2½ billion for the Pacific Highway over the next decade—a commitment that we have had before from the previous government and that then has been withdrawn—obviously without concern, without understanding of the transport industry, and without respect for those who travel on it and for those who unfortunately die on it.

With that, I would like to make reference to a recent report issued by the Federal Office of Road Safety comparing OECD nations. Importantly, the international comparisons of road deaths as a measure of public health risks associated with road trauma imply the point of sensibility and necessity of having national uniform regulatory regimes.

In fatalities per 100,000 in 1994, Australia is ranked ninth in OECD nations with 10.8 road fatalities per 100,000 population. This figure, whilst it undoubtedly could be better, is in fact below the OECD median and, critically, is below the fatalities per 100,000 people of years past. In 1970 we had 30.4 fatalities per 100,000 people in Australia. In 1980, the figure had dropped to 22.3 fatalities per 100,000 people and in 1990 to 13.7 fatalities. But what price do we put on a life? We seem to rejoice when the road toll drops by five or 10, but still that represents hundreds of people too many wasted in carnage.

To give you some examples, from talking to Arthur Baker of Baker's Towing at Bulahdelah, in 1995—just for heavy vehicles—there were 28 heavy vehicle accidents; nine complete road closures—one which lasted two days; two fatal accidents, and the list goes on. Last year on 23 July there was a glass spill which shut the Pacific Highway for a full day. On 25 July, some two days later, an oil spill shut the Pacific Highway yet again. Days later, on 1 August, a chemical spill shut the Pacific Highway yet again.

What are the causes? Everyone could quite easily tag it as being driver fatigue, but there are many causes. It could be equipment failure and, indeed, in some of those accidents equipment failure has been put down as one of the causes. But it is also attributable to it being the worst section of highway in Australia. It is, as I said, a section of highway that has been ignored over the last 13 years, despite the promises and the commitment of $1 billion, we might remember, in 1990 when the member for Charlton (Mr Bob Brown) was the minister for transport and Mr Keating, the then Prime Minister, in his wisdom followed up and pulled out the $1 billion. It is not very good for the people of Bulahdelah who have to go out and clean up some of these messes.

Since the establishment of the National Road Transport Commission, a lot of progress has been made on achieving uniformity of charges and regulations in the road transport industry. To give you some examples, currently a rough average for registration in New South Wales is around $2,800 for a prime mover and $1,400 for a trailer; in Queensland it is $900 for the trailer and $2,500 for the prime mover, and in South Australia $420 for the trailer and $2,500 for the prime mover. So just on trailer registrations there is a variation of over $1,000. What puts it into even further jeopardy—and there are a lot of trucks and trailers in my electorate registered in South Australia—is that you only have to have one inspection at the time of purchase.

One of the things that these regulations do seek to change is that under part 2, division 1, section 11, the registration authority is not to register heavy vehicles based outside its jurisdiction. Quite clearly, it is saying that people must prove that the state they register their vehicles in must be their base of operation. The excuse put forward by South Australia is that there are enough registration inspections at roadsides throughout Australia to pick up problems.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is clearly known throughout the trucking industry that these black spots of inspection—not the black spots of roads—are transmitted on radio frequencies and drivers who are overloaded and drivers with poor quality equipment will take detours, stop trucks, do anything they can, to avoid going through them.

This set of regulations goes a long way towards establishing a safer road network and a safer system of transport in Australia for all Australians. I think it is the right of every employer and driver in the transport industry to be able to pick up a load in Perth and drive through South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland to Darwin with that same load on without having to be challenged on the registration of the vehicle, on the quality of inspection of the vehicle, on the load that is on the vehicle, and on the regulations that it has complied with. I think these regulations go a long way towards establishing clear links that show that this government is serious about the transport industry.

I speak quite regularly with people in the transport industry, such as John Farragher from the John Farragher Transport Group, which has a couple of hundred trucks based in my electorate; Joe Sepos from Sepos Transport, which has some 175 trucks in my electorate; Horns Transport, which is a major coal contractor, and Mountain Bulk Haulage, which is one of the biggest contractors in New South Wales under varying names. One of the biggest things that those people have put to me is that, quite simply, the cowboys in the industry are destroying it for all.

I think the days of the `Mad Dog Morgan' truck drivers will soon be long gone. The time is coming when there needs to be a sense of responsibility and professionalism in the industry. Through these regulations I am sure that we will be starting the process of achieving uniform regulations across the broad spectrum of the transport industry. It is a process that will see the eradication of a few more cowboys and we will see less accidents per year.

But such a process does not come easy. There will be objections from within sectors of the transport industry. As I said, the people in my electorate who are involved in the industry applaud the government. The move towards self‐regulation and self‐inspection for those who can comply with the self‐inspection process takes another unnecessary burden off small business. For large trucking companies such as Sepos and Farragher to have to take their vehicles to inspection stations, when they have their own full‐blown facilities for stripping and rebuilding trucks, inspecting and checking—and they run an extremely clean outfit—is rather ludicrous. It is a cost impost and, more importantly, a time impost which leads to a loss of business.

In summing up, the minister is to be congratulated. I look forward to working with him to make sure that these regulations are implemented. Now that Thiess Contractors has been nominated as the preferred tenderer for the Bulahdelah to Coolongolook section of road, we can look forward to the contracts being finalised, to the road being started and to it being completed just after the end of this term of government. The continuation of that road will make it safe for those who travel upon it. It will reduce the fatalities and it will allow people to get on with their lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend these important cognate bills on road transport reforms to the parliament. They form an integral part of the national road transport reform program being brought to fruition, on a cooperative basis, by the Commonwealth, state and territory governments. For far too long, the economic viability and efficiency of the nation's road transport system has been compromised and undermined by each of the states and territories pursuing fragmented, inconsistent and contradictory road regulations, and the previous speaker mentioned the matter of some of the vehicles not being inspected on a regular basis in some of the states.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 and the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Bill 1996 achieve the government's objective to introduce national road transport reforms designed to produce improvements in road safety and transport efficiency and reduce the costs of administering road transport across Australia. The bills are a significant component of transport micro‐economic reform.

A national uniform regime for road transport regulations will deliver substantial benefits to the industry, its users and the wider community, as well as to the national economy. It will remove the frustration, delays, inefficiencies and costs linked with differences in the regulatory frameworks of the various states and territories. Australia has a huge transport industry which, in economic terms, exceeds $60 billion a year.

In my electorate of Riverina, the city of Wagga Wagga is the headquarters of many trucking companies, large and small. It is also a centre for maintenance for those trucking organisations. In Wagga Wagga we have the headquarters of Finemores, one of the largest transport operators in Australia. This company and the others bring many jobs to the Riverina and particularly to Wagga Wagga. Finemores is a progressive company which generates enormous job opportunities and injects millions of dollars into the Riverina and national economies.

One thing I like about Finemores, and no doubt it is reflected in other companies, is the training program they provide for drivers, both in safety and in the management of their vehicles. One of the touches I like about many trucks today is that on the back of them they have a phone number and a request for you to phone the company and let them know if, in your opinion, a driver is doing a good job or not.

An efficient and cost‐effective transport industry is vital to the ongoing development of Australia and has a critical role to play in the movement of diverse freight, such as food and manufactured goods, to consumers across the country. Twenty per cent of the cost of goods is attributed to transport costs, and the bulk of that occurs on our road network. Any strategy to introduce uniform national transport regulations in order to reduce costs is welcome, as those cost reductions translate into more jobs and lower prices to consumers. This is especially important in rural and regional Australia as transport costs are an additional input to prices charged to consumers there compared with those for people living in the cities.

Australia is a vast country with one of the most extensive road networks in the world, comprising 810,000 kilometres of public roads, and this makes it essential to have an efficient and uniform national road transport regulatory regime. Our road network is used by a national fleet of 11 million vehicles of which about half a million are heavy transport vehicles. For non‐bulk commodities, road is Australia's dominant domestic transport mode. In terms of tonnage moved, 69 per cent of freight is consigned by road. When measured by tonnes per kilometre, road freight comprises 34 per cent of the transport task. Ninety per cent of the transport task is performed on the major routes that comprise 20 per cent of the total network by length. The remaining 80 per cent of roads perform only 10 per cent of the transport task.

A key component of the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996 is the safe movement of dangerous goods on our road network. The movement of dangerous goods by road does pose a threat and a danger to other road users, as well as to city and urban areas through which the heavy vehicles travel. Authorities must always be vigilant in these situations and the transport industry involved in the movement of dangerous goods has a huge responsibility to ensure every safety precaution is taken and every regulation is observed in order to protect the wider community.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may have read in the papers this week, as I did, of the unfortunate death of a motorist when the load shifted on a truck and the timber crushed his vehicle—I think that accident was in Sydney. You may also have read as recently as this morning of another accident when a steel beam passed through another vehicle, narrowly missing taking a person's head off.

I remember that, as a member representing a large electorate—and I represented a very large electorate and travelled about a million kilometres in a motor vehicle in 11 or 12 years—there were many instances where pieces came off the backs of trucks. I remember once a steel rim came off a truck and if it had bounced the wrong way I would not be here today—I would not have had a head. So it is important that we also look at that particular section of the road transport industry. While I do not think we should be over‐regulatory, we must do something about that. As I have said, in my own experience the number of pieces of equipment that fell off the backs of trucks narrowly missing the car were many indeed.

Although Australia's road safety record is equal to the best in the world, accidents do happen. Fortunately, our professional transport industry, our national uniform regulations and our network of highly skilled and trained full‐time emergency service personnel, along with volunteers, have always combined to prevent major disasters when accidents invariably occur. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, all trucks travelling today have to carry a manifest to let us know what is on them in case there is an accident. It is not only important to know what is on the truck but to know exactly where it is on the truck, because if you have to go and handle a situation you may have a problem.

On a lighter note, I remember coming across an accident once where a truck had been carrying a load of bees, and the bees were off the back of the truck and in the middle of the road. This was in the middle of a large town. I must say the emergency service had a problem on their hands there—not as dangerous as in some accidents, but certainly a lively situation.
I thank the parliament for providing me with information on dangerous goods being carried on vehicles. I would like to read this shipping document manifest into the Hansard. It says:
Dangerous Goods cannot be transported unless the appropriate Shipping Documentation is available in the Driver's Cab.
That Documentation must include:

1) A detailed description of the Dangerous Goods, including Class of Dangerous Goods and the United Nations (UN) Dangerous Good Number. This UN Number is specific to the particular Dangerous Goods being transported and provides Emergency response personnel with clear information about the type of Dangerous Goods being transported.

2) The second element of the Shipping document is the Emergency Procedure Guide for the Dangerous Goods being transported. This Guide provides essential emergency response information, including what to do in an Emergency situation.
This shipping documentation is aligned with all transport modes and is harmonised with international Dangerous Goods requirements.
In addition, the vehicle must be clearly placarded with Dangerous Good Class Diamonds indication, the primary physical hazard indication associated with the dangerous goods.

However, an accident on the Hume Highway last year, which involved a heavy vehicle carrying hazardous materials, highlighted several serious anomalies. I am pleased that most of these have been addressed in the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill 1996.

However, the manifest still needs to be kept in a set place within the prime mover to enable easy access by firefighters or other rescue operatives, particularly in a case where the driver is unconscious or may have been killed. A report was prepared on the particular accident that I mentioned. It is interesting to read this report because, while the manifest has to be in these trucks today, there is some argument about exactly where in the truck it should be. The report on that accident says:

The manifest was OK but its positioning in the truck inside the drivers side door, as required by legislation, was not considered appropriate. In this particular accident it was not possible to gain access to the manifest due to the nature of the accident. A (trucking company) representative suggested that a better location for the manifest would be under the passengers side seat. Already a lot of computer equipment is stored in this location on . . . trucks and experience has shown that to be, generally, the best accessible location following an accident.

I have written to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) about that. I asked him to take that on board. Only research will show whether that is the right place for it or whether it should be, as it is now, inside the driver's side door. I have raised this matter with the minister and have urged him to look at the problem of easy access to the truck manifest.

Another important element of the safe transport of dangerous goods is the coalition government's black spot roads program which will, over time, upgrade Australia's most dangerous roads. As part of this crucial road safety strategy, the government will spend $36 million a year in real terms over a four‐year period. As a representative of the vast and important rural electorate of Riverina—the food bowl of Australia—I am pleased that 50 per cent of these funds will be allocated to rural and regional roads.

As other members have done, I have put out a press statement asking people in my electorate to let me know of black spots. I received a letter the other day about a black spot on the Hume Highway and, while the Hume Highway is not in my electorate, this example will give the House an indication of the problem. This person was writing about an area that has a dual carriageway, with a concrete road, so you would think everything would be all right.

The problem is with a sidetrack into a service station. The concrete leading into that sidetrack ends at a very sharp angle, so when a truck goes onto the side to go down the bypass, it moves off the concrete onto the gravel. This has created an enormous hole. The person who wrote to me said that he had wiped out the front end of his car in the hole. All that is needed is another metre of concrete on that angle, extended on either side, thus phasing it in. That may save lives. That example is an indication of one of the black spots which could be fixed up without great expense.

BREAK.PARA: Changes in regulations invariably cause problems for some individuals, and no doubt this will happen within the transport industry. While these bills will generate enormous benefits for the transport industry and the broader community, I am confident that those operators who feel that they may be adversely affected by the reforms will be given a fair hearing by the different state jurisdictions. I commend these bills to the House and I congratulate the government for introducing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Amendment Bill. I appreciate the excellent work done on transport reform to date by Minister Sharp, his staff and the department. I also appreciate that the aim of the act is to provide for the safe and efficient transport of dangerous goods across Australia, albeit by using present links available including through urban areas and historic villages.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that improving the administration and the enforcement of the procedures set in plan for the transportation of dangerous goods are certainly noble intentions. However, the act does not take into account three critical factors and I raise these in the knowledge of how they would affect and relate to my electorate of Gilmore.

Firstly, the act fails to take into consideration the standard of roads we inherited and on which the dangerous goods are to be transported. The potential for disaster because of poor maintenance cannot be neutralised by regulations. To introduce such regulations for the safety of goods being transported would, of course, be welcome. However, we all understand that transport is only as safe as the roads upon which it travels and I concede that for the most part this service is excellent.

We as a government can regulate all we like but as long as the roads are not up to scratch then the potential for an accident is always going to be extreme. My electorate of Gilmore is a perfect example. It is a dead end when it comes to the moving of goods by road transport. As well, there is no other transportation choice, as the railway system from the southern end of Sydney comes to a halt in my electorate. Therefore, the only option is transport by road.

We have a number of small manufacturers and two major manufacturers in the Shoalhaven that have national markets—the Shoalhaven paper mill and the Manildra group producing starch and ethanol. Both of these companies, which are the largest employers in the area, process and require large amounts of chemicals to be transported in bulk in and out of the area on roads that not only go through historic villages and urban areas but that are also, in many cases, substandard. The major arteries into Nowra from the Hume Highway and all points south and west are either via Batemans Bay or through the historic township of Kangaroo Valley, adding some hundreds of dollars to a trip in fuel and running costs because of the added distance, not to mention the added stress that is incurred by the drivers.

To illustrate the inadequacy and the potential for danger of this road, Minister Sharp and I were recently invited by Hitchcock's Haulage of Bomaderry to join them on two loaded semitrailers on a run from Moss Vale to Bomaderry through Kangaroo Valley to experience what to them is everyday life. The journey was a real eye‐opener for both of us. Had it not been for the skill and expertise of the drivers, the near misses we experienced could undoubtedly have been a lot more serious. It was very easy to see the potential for disaster with the drivers relying on each other's expertise to avoid such incidents—not to mention the anger and frustration of those having the misfortune to be behind them.

This potential would almost be eliminated if main road 92 were to be built from the coast to Canberra, using a link out of the city centre and travelling through sparsely populated areas yet linking the region to the city. No longer would semitrailers laden with dangerous goods need to travel through the historic Kangaroo Valley and, in particular, the very dangerous road could then revert to being a tourist route—for which it was designed—linking Sydney with the southern highlands, Canberra, the Shoalhaven and Illawarra. Apart from the question of safety, the socioeconomic implications are enormous. Once again the lifestyle of a village could be restored without the fear of a disaster about to occur.

Another valuable asset to the Shoalhaven is HMAS Albatross which is being upgraded in its role as a major defence maintenance facility. Its services are being exported to South‐East Asia and there is need for close links to Canberra to allow for embassy liaisons and to provide a strategic defence link between HMAS Albatross, HMAS Cresswell and Canberra. The Department of Defence will, of course, also be bound by the dangerous goods act, so main road 92 would provide the safe, speedy link that is required.

It is pleasing to note that the defence forces are already making a start on parts of main road 92 for their own benefit and the future potential of the base and in turn my electorate as a whole. I thank the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) for recogning of this potential.

The second item I raise with regard to this legislation is the environmental concerns of transporting dangerous goods through areas of strategic environmental importance. The impact of road transport on Australia's environment is significant and I do not believe safety concerns with regard to environmental issues have been of sufficient focus in the dangerous goods act.
I will quote from the recent report of the review board, Transport law and the future of the National Road Transport Commission (NRTC):

Road transport is the single largest source of air pollution in major urban areas in Australia. It accounts for about 12% of greenhouse gas emissions. As such, the impact of road transport on Australia's environment is significant.

The review of the NRTC notes the environmental issues so far have not been a focus of the reform process. It acknowledges the need for greater consideration of the environmental impact of changes to road transport regulation. In essence, it recommends that . . . the National Road Transport Commission be required to consult, to the mutual satisfactory of both parties, with the National Environmental Protection Council Committee on all road transport issues having significant environmental impacts.

I support these recommendations and again use my electorate of Gilmore as an example. Gilmore is an area that boasts some of the most spectacular scenery in Australia, and I believe the socioeconomic future of Gilmore rests with this beautiful scenery in the form of its attraction to tourists, mainly for ecotourism, for both domestic and international markets.

In considering the transport of dangerous goods I ask: what plans has the government for protecting fragile environmental areas from accidents and spills that we hope will never eventuate? Regulations at a federal and state level are necessary, but not always adhered to. Furthermore, accidents are generally caused by inexperienced drivers who are not subject to the regulations.

I must again emphasise that the safety of pristine areas, of which my electorate is a proud keeper, cannot be guaranteed by regulations alone and you cannot regulate against accidents. The impact of a spill of dangerous goods on flora and fauna in the Gilmore electorate would be disastrous. Fragile areas such as Jervis Bay and national parks would take many years to recover, if ever, from such an accident. Another scenario that brings shivers to the spine is a petrol tanker spill on the Batemans Bay bridge. The environment would be ruined and that would mean economic disaster for the fishing industry, the oyster industry and the tourism industry.

Although I talk on the subject of my electorate of Gilmore in regard to the environment, I must refer to the 1993 report of the Resource Assessment Commission. This report is the most substantial of almost 60 reports which have been undertaken on Australia's coastal zone since the 1960s. The report identified a need for an integrated national approach involving local, state and Commonwealth governments to address the problems of the coastal zone. The inquiry found that no single sphere of government can manage the zone, and issues of national significance and great public concern are involved; the socioeconomic development of the coastal zone is of profound importance to this nation; and, most importantly, Australia has international obligations in the zone that necessitate coordination between the spheres of government.

Our coastal zone, with its estuaries, contains ecologically important habitats, and on the whole our marine and estuarine environments are in good condition. However, the problems of coastal pollution have been recognised and it is our responsibility not only to put a stop to the progress of pollution but to reverse the trend, and certainly to do all we can to prevent the potential disaster of a spill of dangerous goods. There are options such as a link road that eliminate these serious concerns for my electorate. I will quote briefly from Australia's state of the environment report of 1996:
Air toxin emissions by vehicles are an emerging issue through urban and coastal areas requiring further investigation.

The final factor not addressed by this dangerous goods act is the lack of a contingency plan should the worst scenario happen. I have said previously that it is impossible to regulate against accidents. I cannot stress enough the importance of looking at better roads when complimenting this bill—in particular, for my electorate, main road 92. This is certainly an issue that would involve all levels of government.
The social and economic future of Gilmore is tied to the potential of its environmental assets. A dangerous goods spill would have a devastating effect on our economy and community.

Again I congratulate all those involved in the preparation of the dangerous goods act, and I ask that they give serious consideration to the points referred to. Also I commend the minister for transport and his department on work being done so far on main road 92, as I commend the Shoalhaven Council for allocating considerable funds for research to this most important road link, not just for the Gilmore electorate but for New South Wales and Australia as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson, Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to keep the chamber here for too long but in summing up I would just like to thank all participants in this debate. I have been listening intently to what has been said from both sides of the House and I would congratulate all members on the nature and extent of their contribution to this debate. I think that it has been extremely worth while.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Melbourne and the shadow minister (Mr Tanner), raised questions about the need for the government to heed the issues of heavy vehicle safety, driving hours and vehicle maintenance. I can assure him that the government is acutely aware of that and is already paying close attention to these areas.

BREAK.PARA: The road transport reforms being developed by the National Road Transport Commission—the NRTC—are intended to cover a wide range of transport activities. Registration and dangerous goods are only two of six regulatory models which fall within that reform program. Other modules include: truck driving hours; heavy vehicle standards; compliance and enforcement; and driver licensing. I commend to Mr Tanner those transport reforms that are being developed and I respectfully suggest he has a close look at that program. I think it will answer a number of his queries.

The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), raised the concern about the types of dangerous goods being transported and the public's right to know, and that is a very legitimate point. The new dangerous goods regime that I was talking about before which has been developed by the NRTC contains strict requirements for dangerous goods, with the vehicle to be clearly placarded in accordance with international requirements. These placards include colour symbols and written warnings which indicate to all road users the nature of the hazard posed by those dangerous goods. I can assure the honourable member that the government is acutely aware of that and I think that he would be well satisfied with the regime that has been put in place.

The member for Calare (Mr Andren), raised the question of who is going to foot the bill for road and bridge damage from the increase in heavy vehicle limits and the associated transport costs. The mass limits of individual vehicles are part of the NRTC's legislative reforms. There has been extensive consultation with local governments and others in relation to that. In effect, operators who wish to avail themselves of any increased mass will be required to pay additional charges to recover the cost of any additional road damage. This arrangement will affect only large operators and will result in an amendment to the Road Transport Charges (Australian Capital Territory) Act 1993.

The member for Calare also raised the question of the representation of community groups in relation to deliberations that led to these amendments. Under the NRTC Act 1991, there is a strict requirement for the NRTC to consult with representatives of people who live in rural or remote areas where appropriate and practicable to do so. Furthermore, section 10(d) of the act requires that all interested people, bodies and organisations be involved in the consultative process, and I believe that has been attended to.

The member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), raised a question about Point Lillias. That is ostensibly a state government matter and, to the extent that the transport of dangerous goods is a state and territory responsibility, we have no strict regulatory responsibility in that area, although, as I indicated earlier, the new dangerous goods regulatory regime is designed to facilitate the safe transport of dangerous goods and compliance with those new regulations will provide for the highest possible level of safety regardless of locational factors.
I hope that is of assistance to those honourable members in particular. Again, I would like to thank all members of the House for their contribution to this debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROAD TRANSPORT REFORM (HEAVY VEHICLES REGISTRATION) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Public Service Amendment Bill 1996. It is, in its intention and execution, a very simple bill to correct a procedural flaw, the correction of which would have the unanimous support of the House. Therefore, I will speak about that only very briefly.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is one concern that the opposition has had with the bill. We have considered it very carefully. We have received generous cooperation from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) and from the department in consideration of that concern and, on balance, we are prepared to accept the proposition the government puts with regard to that. Let me deal with those two things in detail, but not at length.

The bill proposes an amendment to the Public Service Act to deal with, as I said in my opening remarks, a procedural flaw. This procedural flaw arises in the discipline provisions of the act; it was never intended and, clearly, it is anomalous. We have a situation at the moment whereby the act does not enable the bringing of valid discipline charges against an officer of the Australian Public Service who has resumed duties in a department after a period as an unattached officer where the misconduct alleged took place when the officer was so unattached, as defined in the act.

Nobody ever intended that there should be a circumstance in which an offence for which one was liable to be charged when it was committed should be open to a defence that the officer concerned had changed status between the offence and the laying of the charge and therefore in some way the officer should be protected from dealing with that charge in a manner that every other officer in the Public Service would have to confront. That was never the intention. It is simply an unintended consequence and we support the intention to correct it. I will waste no more time on that. In my view, everybody in the House and everybody I know in the Public Service supports that proposition.

Therefore, why does the bill need any consideration at all? We could just pass it on the nod. It is because there is within the propositions an element of retrospectivity, and every time that arises everybody in the parliament on both sides, and the independent members, want to give that a lot of consideration. I know from discussion with the minister that that was a concern that he had. He took significant efforts to reassure himself that it was not an element of retrospectivity that was either unwarranted or adversely affected the rights of those affected in a way that should give concern to the House.

I took a lot of time and consulted with colleagues who have been associated with this both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. The Senate has a lot of history of dealing with this by virtue of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee which examines all legislation for any matters that might affect the rights of a citizen, including retrospectivity.

BREAK.PARA: The most important factor in minimising any concern about retrospectivity is that a simple description of the anomaly we are correcting makes it clear that this bill, through proposed sections 63(L), 10 and 11, while it does give retrospective application to proposed subsection 9, in respect of persons who cease to be unattached officers or engaged in misconduct before the commencement of a subsection, does not create an offence that was not an offence at the time the incident occurred. The incident was an offence. What has changed is the removal of a technical defence, or a procedural defence, which the unattached officer might have had.

That is not an irrelevant factor nevertheless, even though what we are saying is that the conduct, if it is an offence now, was an offence at the time it was committed. It is almost certain—I think it is beyond question—that the individual officer would have believed they were liable for action under the Public Service Act. I do not believe there was anybody out there saying, `Well, I can act in a way that would otherwise lead me to face disciplinary proceedings, because I have this procedural defence available to me that will protect me.' I do not think there is anybody who felt they were not in jeopardy and that their rights were not at risk who will confront an unexpected vulnerability to being charged under the Public Service Act.

The principles that are involved, while they are important, need to be assessed against the circumstances of the individual piece of legislation. If we have a circumstance where any disciplinary procedure is, on its face, and in this instance in fact, retrospective, it is not a matter to be dealt with lightly. But, conversely, it is not a matter which should freeze us into inactivity. We are not endangering any right that anybody had or believed they had at the time of the offence. In so far as the incident occurred or the alleged offence might have taken place in any particular case, the ground rules are being subsequently changed, but not in any way that I believe offends the principle of retrospectivity that would give concern to the House or the Senate.

The opposition, like the government, gave substantial consideration to whether this issue of retrospectivity was such that it should cause us not to support what would otherwise be an innocuous bill which we would support in a straightforward manner. On balance, we are convinced that the bill should proceed as proposed and that there is no need for the House to be so concerned with the retrospective application. I do not believe the Senate will consider it should take any particular action with regard to this matter.

While we support the bill, I do not think it will affect very many people. It is a rare circumstance, first, that anybody is charged under the Public Service Act at all or, secondly, that unattached officers are charged under the Public Service Act. It is even less common that they should then come back to their department as an attached officer in the period between the incident in question and the proceedings being initiated. By the time you had all those processes, it is a very rare circumstance that anybody is going to confront such a matter, but certainly it is conceivable and some of the possibilities might arise quite quickly.

Whether or not that is the case, the public expects that the parliament will have the legislation in proper order so that, if an offence has taken place, proper proceedings can be initiated with regard to it without procedural defects providing procedural defences that do not go to the merits of the matter. For those reasons and, briefly, because that is what the circumstance warrants, the opposition will be supporting the bill and cooperating in its speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The standing and integrity of the Public Service must be at all times beyond reproach. That that is the case in relation particularly to people in the diplomatic corps goes without saying. The diplomatic corps is probably the most visible presence of our country overseas. Consequently, it is absolutely essential to ensure that legislation is in place which will work evenly both across members of that corps who may have been appointed by the Governor‐General and across the whole Public Service structure.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no secret that, for a number of years, questions have been raised about the behaviour of some diplomats overseas, particularly in South‐East Asia. Cooperative international relations and the passing of Crimes Act legislation some years ago has now seen tourists being charged for interfering with children. Recently, a committal proceeding occurred here in Canberra where a former diplomat was charged with certain offences involving the exploitation and sexual abuse of children.

It is a truism—as those involved in the criminal law are well aware—to say that charges of this nature are the easiest to make and often the most difficult to refute. However, I am not so sure that that principle necessarily applies in situations that we have experienced under the operation of this act. It is particularly acute when cultural and ethnic differences enter the equation and where there is a requirement for interpreters. Obviously, the best defence is frequently the assertion that the complainant was induced to make the complaint for monetary, accommodation or other considerations. I would think—and this is a wider issue, admittedly—that evidentiary provisions need to be introduced to permit the taking of evidence from children by way of video presentation, as is currently done in Queensland, for complaints of this nature. That does not prohibit cross‐examination of the complainant for the provisions to work.

The Public Service Amendment Bill 1996 clarifies the presumption which underpins the parent legislation—that is, that unattached officers are liable to Public Service disciplinary procedures. It is a fairly reasonable assumption that this bill has flowed from some of the allegations that have arisen in recent times along the lines that I have mentioned.

The bill has particular application to the diplomatic corps. The act defines `unattached officer' for discipline purposes as an officer who is in employment outside the department and is not performing duty in the department, or an officer who is on certain types of leave of absence from the service and does not hold an office in the department. An officer ceases to be unattached upon resumption of duty in the department. Heads of Australian diplomatic missions who were officers of the service prior to becoming heads of diplomatic missions are unattached officers while performing the role of head of mission.

It has been argued—and the argument appears to have been largely unresolved—that diplomats, although public servants per se, are not susceptible to Public Service disciplinary procedures. However, it equally can be argued that the intention always was that diplomats are public servants first and foremost and, therefore, should be liable to Public Service rules and guidelines. The existing legislation had exhibited a weakness in this respect, and the amending bill removes the doubt by making unattached officers expressly liable to Public Service disciplinary procedures.
