The question of retrospectivity, as has been mentioned by the honourable member for Canberra (Mr McMullan), is a very important one, and it is one on which I have reflected at some length. The government itself in fact teased out the potential problem, rather than any particular case situation having arisen. If it had arisen, and if there were particular case situations involved, I would have reflected much more strongly about the position I would take in relation to supporting the particular bill.

But, having examined what had occurred, and having examined the fact that the government identified what was a potential problem and now seeks, by way of legislation, to entrench the already established view that unattached officers are in no different a position from that of run‐of‐the‐mill public servants, my view is that it does not affect the rule against retrospectivity. In all of the circumstances, while these issues are never easy and require the utmost care, it is my view in this case that this particular piece of legislation does not impinge upon that very well settled principle.

The bill, in my submission, is a good bill. In effect, it demonstrates the keen perception of the department to ensure that this particular area does not go unattended and does not leave a potential anomaly in the legislation. It is important obviously, as I said at the very outset, that these particular matters are tidied up and that an even approach across the board is exhibited in respect of matters of this nature.

As I said right at the beginning, it is entirely correct for the insurance and maintenance of a respected Public Service that provisions of this nature apply across the board and can deal with a potential situation as and when it might arise. For all of those reasons, and accepting the reservations of the honourable member for Canberra and others in relation to the bill, I am satisfied that this particular bill does not transgress the principle against retrospectivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Public Service Amendment Bill 1996. My colleague the honourable member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) has well outlined the reasonable case for the bill. I want to say that this matter arises here before us because we have a whole series of very detailed regulations. Whenever we have legislation and regulations that deal in great detail with prescribing the actions of individuals, the circumstances under which they work, the circumstances under which they can be disciplined or dismissed and the circumstances under which they can transfer from one operation of a department, group or defined organisation to another, we wind up ultimately with problems and anomalies.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the world's simplest law was probably written back in biblical times. Yet, if you needed to modify one of the 10 commandments or describe all the circumstances now that might apply to that commandment, I suspect we might have volumes instead of one sheet of paper that has writ large the 10 commandments that came down from the mountain.

I was told that the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), in his contribution on Austudy in the main chamber of the House of Representatives this morning, referred to remarks I had made earlier about some detail of Austudy regulations. Without going into detail on that bill, as that would be inappropriate because we are dealing with the Public Service Amendment Bill at this particular point in time, I point out to this chamber that the point about the Austudy bill is that it is an attempt to define benefits and to prescribe who is eligible.

Certainly, it is laudatory that we have as an objective to help with their living expenses students who do not have the means to go to university. As soon as we create a defined benefits scheme, we have to create rules. The rules create anomalies, the anomalies create anomalies, and then we have to write rules to address the anomalies. The more complex it gets, the further away we get from actually targeting the benefit to the individuals who really need it.

BREAK.PARA: Sometimes we confuse ourselves, but today we are addressing an issue about a complex set of regulations. Those regulations cover such things as whether an unattached officer, who is still in the employ of the Commonwealth, who did something wrong and cannot be caught under the provisions of that detailed set of prescriptions and regulations, should be able to be caught when he comes back to work in the Commonwealth public sector.

The Public Service Act is a very complex, detailed set of rules and regulations. I am informed by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith), who has joined us here today, that those rules and regulations are so complex that we waste tens of thousands of man hours and hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars every year in dealing with the prescription of the regulation rather than trying to get the outcome that we are trying to achieve.

In terms of the Public Service Act, the outcome we are trying to achieve is to make sure that employees are treated fairly and reasonably, that they have the opportunity to move from one employment opportunity when they work for the Commonwealth to another employment opportunity, without having to resign or retire or go outside and then come back inside—to give them a chance. That is fair, but surely we should be able to make it simpler. As long as it is as complex as it is we will be in here time and time again rewriting the rules and regulations in order to deal with the anomalies. It is the anomalies that create more rules.

Have a look at superannuation. It was simple 25 years ago, was it not? I thought it was pretty simple, with a very tightly confined act, and today it is so complex that I defy you to find a single person in this nation who totally comprehends all of the superannuation regulations and details of that act.

The Public Service Amendment Bill is far too complex. It deals with such complex issues as how individuals relate to other individuals, how they work together—a long string of procedures that must be followed before a person who has really done something wrong or is not doing the job at all can be asked to work for someone else somewhere else.

We used to call it the civil service. Then we called it the public service, and sometimes I wonder if the emphasis is on service to the public or in fact the emphasis is on the public service itself. It is the detail in the prescription that bothers me. I wish that we could simplify these matters and simply allow people to work together to achieve, if you will, better outcomes rather than to achieve the detail of prescription that is required by these matters.

Madam Deputy Speaker, under all the circumstances I certainly support the Public Service Amendment Bill. I deplore the fact that it is necessary to create this particular amendment bill. Be that as it may: it is, and it is here before us today. I thank the opposition for supporting the bill as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Mr REITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations, Leader of the House and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate on the Public Service Amendment Bill. I think it is fair to say that the contributions from the members for La Trobe (Mr Charles), Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) and Canberra (Mr McMullan) have been colourful, controversial, comprehensive and considered. The full range of issues has been covered. The comments from the member for Canberra I think were particularly succinct in setting out the essential issues contained and addressed in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst there are many complex issues in the Public Service Act 1922 and the government has a general policy prescription of moving to streamline the operations and processes within the Public Service itself, in respect of this particular matter there is a fairly concise and easily stated problem that this legislation attempts to deal with. The current form of the disciplinary provisions does not enable disciplinary action to be taken against an officer who was but is no longer unattached in relation to possible misconduct that occurred while unattached. The proposed amendment to the act seeks to permit disciplinary action to be taken with respect to a formerly unattached officer as if he or she were still unattached.

As the member for Canberra said, it does not create an offence but it does address a technical obstacle to the prosecution of matters pursuant to those disciplinary processes. He also canvassed the question of retrospectivity, as he referred to it, in his remarks. It was a matter that immediately caught my eye in the initial briefings that I had on the matter. We have fairly exhaustively sought advice and satisfied ourselves that the course of action does not in any way breach the standards and the general view which has been expressed by many on both sides of the House on the question of retrospectivity as it has been raised on other occasions in respect of other issues.

I think more generally it is fair to say that, when you consider the question of retrospectivity, there is not necessarily a hard and fast rule. There are many legislative enactments which provide or have some retrospective effect. In fact, when you think of it, there are certainly legislative instruments that have a retrospective effect which is beneficial to the persons affected, and obviously in most circumstances they have no problems. The honourable member also referred to one of the tests when it comes to retrospectivity; that is, whether or not an individual had an expectation of the validity of their conduct at the particular time, and he made the point that no‐one could have had such an expectation of the validity of their acts given the nature of the offences which might come within these disciplinary provisions.

The issue of retrospectivity was also canvassed in the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and I think it gives added reassurance to members that the conclusions that were come to on both sides of the House are reasonable and proper in all of the circumstances. Madam Deputy Speaker, I appreciate the support that we have had and the cooperation from all members, including the member for Canberra. I commend the bill to the Main Committee and then to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting the Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. The bill amends a number of minor provisions in various pieces of Commonwealth criminal legislation. The opposition is of the view that we should support those particular corrections and amendments. The Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice (Mr Williams), in his second reading speech, outlined a number of bills to be amended. I think it will be worth while, shortly, to go to some of those provisions.

BREAK.PARA: The Crimes Act 1914 is to be amended, taking into account item 9 of schedule 1. It will increase the penalty unit of all Commonwealth offences from $100 to $110. This is in accordance with a CPI increase of 9.6 per cent during the period June 1992 to September 1995, the period since penalty units were originally introduced. So this mean spirited government, in many other respects, is now going to index penalty units. I wonder whether this is going to be a continuing thing.

The opposition supports the amendments on this occasion but I put the government on notice that we will look at this in the future. I do not think it is good policy to be indexing penalty units or fines on a regular basis. As someone who practised as a legal aid solicitor, and a legal aid barrister, my view is that, in many instances, a maximum fine is not imposed and that magistrates and judges award something lesser.

The only reason that we would want to change the penalty units is if it is fairly obvious that we need to look at a particular penalty or range of penalties that need a substantial increase. For instance, in New South Wales recently, we had the instance where people were invading the pitch at the Sydney Cricket Ground. It was felt that the penalty of $100 was too small and so for a deterrence effect it has been agreed by all political parties that that penalty be increased to $5,000. I think that is a better approach than the government coming back to the parliament every so often and saying, `Let's have a CPI increase for these penalties.' But, in this instance, the opposition is certainly not opposing that provision.

Another important piece of legislation being corrected, which we agree with, is the Extradition Act 1988. It is to be amended in two minor ways, which are outlined in the Attorney‐General's second reading speech, to correct deficiencies in present provisions. The Attorney said:

The first amendment will make it clear that, if a person makes an application for bail on the merits and fails, the person is not able to make a further application unless there is evidence of a change in circumstances that might justify bail being granted.

Currently, where a magistrate remands a person in custody after the person has made an application for bail, the person is not entitled to apply to any other magistrate for release on bail during that remand. That would be unfair if the person's circumstances change such that bail would be justified but the original magistrate is no longer available, for example, if the original magistrate had resigned or retired. The amendment will overcome this deficiency while still achieving the purpose of restricting `magistrate-shopping.'

I know that there is concern in the community about magistrate shopping, but also I think that those of us who have appeared in courts know that there are some magistrates for whom the standard is not consistent. There are magistrates, frankly, who have refused bail in certain circumstances where it was not warranted. That can be reviewed by appeal to the Supreme Court in New South Wales, for instance.

Whilst I am against magistrate shopping or forum shopping, we need to understand that there are different standards applied by some magistrates—there are some magistrates who are considered doves, and it is the same with judges. But it is a ridiculous situation if people are able to come back time and time again when there are no fresh circumstances in relation to bail. If a determination has been made, then so be it. But let us not be under the misapprehension that magistrates or judges always get it right. Sometimes it is beneficial, if there has not been any other change of circumstances, for people to come back if time has elapsed. The change of circumstances might be—and it can be picked up anyway—that trial dates go off or certain assumptions that a magistrate was acting under have not been followed.

I just raise that because of the assumptions we all make. Judges and magistrates are human. The community needs to understand that, just as we politicians bring our different experiences to the parliament, so do magistrates, so do judges. There is nothing inherently wrong with different sentences or one magistrate refusing bail, or one magistrate granting bail, and it is not alleging that the system is corrupt or whatever. But I do believe that I have seen some cases which illustrate what I am saying.

We had such an instance with the allegations about Pauline Hanson being spat at by young Aboriginal children. I read the other day that, when one of those children came before the court, it was discovered that the offence for which they were kept in custody had been repealed, was non‐existent. That is not necessarily applicable to this, but what I am saying is that magistrates are fallible. One has to ask what was wrong on the first occasion. Why did the magistrate not go to first principles? That is something that I know that some of us who have practised always did, making sure that the charge was still alive. It is easy to criticise from the sidelines; all I am saying is that sometimes there is not a change in circumstances. The change in that instance would have been a discovery that the charge did not exist and you would have brought them back before the court. But I am straying a little bit.

These are minor technical amendments and we think that they should be facilitated, and facilitated quickly. We know that there might be some criticism. I notice that the Alert is critical of the retrospective nature of one of the clauses. That has to do with the War Crimes Tribunal's act, but we support that. That is being backdated to 28 August 1995, but those provisions, we understand, were inserted through a typographical error by way of the International War Crimes Tribunal Act 1995, which commenced on that day. That is an instance where we think the retrospectivity is warranted.

There are a number of other amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, the Customs Act 1901, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 and the Witness Protection Act 1994. All of those things the opposition supports. There is no hidden agenda here. Some of those things were not necessarily known at the time and it is only over time that the errors, be they drafting errors or whatever, have been discovered. So the opposition is happy to support this bill. I will be the only speaker; it is not controversial. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In following the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) in the Main Committee, I note that it seems that the proceedings in the Main Committee attract more lawyers than some of the proceedings on bills in the other place, the main chamber. The particular amendments to the Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, if I can summarise them as briefly as I can, relate to the aggregation and cumulative sentences imposed for corruption offences by Commonwealth employees and Australian Federal Police members and staff members, so that they can be brought within the scope of sentences which trigger the cancellation of employer funded superannuation benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The sentences imposed as an alternative to full‐time imprisonment will not trigger the cancellation of employer funded superannuation benefits. The penalty unit issue has already been mentioned. The following are also dealt with: the Commonwealth being able to recover the costs it incurs in relation to storage and maintenance of confiscated goods such as vehicles and vessels used in drug trafficking; a requirement that a person who has been arrested, having escaped from custody, under the Extradition Act is to be taken before a magistrate who may issue a warrant authorising the return of the person to custody; provisions for extensions of time to be granted for the making of an application in relation to property restrained under the Proceeds of Crimes Act; making a defence of reasonable corporate precaution for offences committed by bodies corporate under the Proceeds of Crimes Act; minor technical corrections to the Proceeds of Crimes Act and the Witness Protection Act; and the requirement to obtain ministerial consent to institute prosecutions under various Commonwealth statutes being removed.

As far as aggregate and cumulative offences are concerned, this deals with the amendment to the Australian Federal Police Act and the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act. Both these acts provide for the cancellation of employer funded superannuation if the offender is convicted of an offence and sentenced to more than 12 months imprisonment. The amendments seek to overcome the situation where a person may receive sentences on separate counts that individually are less than 12 months. In other words, prior to the amendments, the superannuation order would not have been made, would not have been capable of being made, in a situation where individual sentences are less than 12 months, for example, but over the whole are much more than 12 months.

Given the current practices of the court in imposing sentences, with sentences either being cumulative or concurrent, and the aggregate in some cases being over the 12 months, the amendment is in my view quite appropriate. Now the whole of the sentence is taken into account and the superannuation order may be made. Under further amendments the superannuation order may not be made if the sentence imposed is an alternative to full‐time incarceration, even if that sentence is longer than 12 months.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, the strings of amendments in relation to this matter are fairly extensive, but the effect of the amendment under section 45(2)—I think it is—is that a superannuation order may not be made against a person who is convicted of a corruption offence and receives a sentence, for example, of periodic detention, under subsection 20(A)(B) of the Crimes Act, even if the sentence is for a period longer than 12 months. I will have something to say about that shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: As a general proposition, offenders who are guilty of a corruption offence under the Australian Federal Police Act have, in reality, usurped their position to commit their offences and should not, as a matter of principle, reap the benefits of any employee funded superannuation entitlements. In Queensland, we had the notorious case of the disgraced police commissioner, Terry Lewis. There was considerable litigation over his quite massive entitlement to superannuation. Ultimately, as a result of that quite considerable litigation, he did not get his superannuation. I believe this particular amendment will clarify the matter more.

Obviously, the employee, being a person who has used his office to profit by it, or to commit acts which are obviously a gross offence to the integrity of the system, ought not be given a handshake in another sense, as a result of his position of trust and so forth. It is true to say that, if people are minded to commit offences of this nature, the loss of their benefits would not necessarily be a deterrent. If they are caught for the principal offence they will go to prison, particularly if they are police officers. However, this provision ensures that they will suffer financially when they are released. Obviously, if the government does not have to pay the money, it can use the money for more appropriate purposes.

A superannuation order may be revoked if the sentence is reduced or changed to a term not exceeding 12 months. The issue about the amendment that I referred to earlier is one that needs some consideration, but does it go far enough? In these particular cases, the Director of Public Prosecutions cannot make an application for a superannuation order. Just because a person is given home detention does not mean that the crime committed was any less serious. Periodic detention and even a suspension of sentence frequently occur in cases of quite serious crime.

However, it would be very difficult to imagine that a police officer who had been convicted of official corruption would be given a periodic detention order or some form of a suspended sentence. Indeed, in what I would have called a fairly minor case of official corruption, a police officer in Queensland had a sentence of 2½ years imposed. Obviously, this would vary according to the nature of the corruption but, at the very bottom end, I would think that the 2½ years was imposed without remission.

In determining sentences, the court takes into account many factors, not the least of which is the seriousness of the offence. In relation to mitigation, the court takes into account personal factors. I suspect that the operation of this section may need to be looked at again so that the courts are given a discretion. In my view, the court, and this is not a criticism so much as a suggestion, should be able to act of its own motion. In other words, it gives the court a greater discretion. I know that many judges describe the sentencing process as the most difficult part of their judicial life. I am perhaps compounding it even further but I think some element of discretion needs to be applied in this particular area.

The member for Banks mentioned penalty units and the CPI. I find it difficult to disagree with his general proposition. If this legislation were merely to increase the penalty units in accordance with the CPI, I think it would be stretching into flights of fancy. However, it is in conjunction with other measures and I do not necessarily say anything other than that.

The question of recovery of out‐of‐pocket expenses also, I think, requires a little bit of comment. This relates to the expenses incurred relating to the transportation and storage of narcotic related goods that are placed in commercial storage facilities prior to the goods being transferred to the official trustee for disposal. It is interesting that the amendment is limited to this extent. The amendment does not extend to full cost recovery for the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth will not be entitled to recover expenses of staff remuneration such as salary expenses, nor is it entitled to recover expenses that are an ordinary incident of its operation. Ordinary, everyday running costs such as office expenses, telephone and facsimile expenses, et cetera are not recoverable. Rather, it is the extraordinary costs such as the costs of transportation of narcotic related goods to a place of storage and the actual storage charges that are recoverable.

There may be some circumstances, however, where additional costs, which arguably could be out of the ordinary, might relate to the travel of police officers. For example, a police officer who may be on secondment or what have you may necessarily be involved in extensive travel. Could it be argued that that is recoverable because it is `out of the ordinary' costs? I would hope so, because I think the net should be cast as wide as reasonably possible in cases such as this, particularly where the value of the security being held is well in excess of the cost incurred and where the value of the drugs involved is quite massive. There are a lot of comparisons, I would suggest, that ought to be made in relation to that particular matter.

The Extradition Act has also been mentioned by my friend from Banks. The interesting comments that the honourable member made in relation to magistrate shopping were very true. It is the case that not all magistrates exercise discretion in a standard way. It is a discretion after all. It is true that going to one magistrate on a fairly pedestrian bail application is sometimes a very nauseating experience because the result is always foretold. You know exactly what is going to happen. But going to another magistrate, you know that, while you may not succeed, you will get the sort of hearing that one would come to expect in those sorts of applications. It is interesting that at common law, in fact, the very people going and seeking bail, which in effect is in the nature of habeas corpus—in a sense, you are seeking the release of a person—were able to go to different judges and shop around and do that. It was not frowned upon at all. Indeed, the Queensland Bail Act does permit that to occur. In practice, of course, the reality is that, if you went to one particular judge and then later that day went to another judge, I would not like your chances before that second judge once he was informed—as he would have been—that the application was refused before judge A. I sometimes wonder about the legislative notion about magistrate shopping, because the common law, in my view, had taken care of that fairly well.

With regard to the restraining of property of defendants charged with certain offences, the amendment is sensible in my view. This obviously is a problem area. The previous legislation made it necessary for persons to get their application in before the court within the six‐month period, otherwise the court had no jurisdiction to hear the application. Obviously, that caused an awful clogging of the lists of the court. That could not really cause anything other than problems for the rest of the court lists. In other words, this is a very sensible amendment in my view.

The next issue is the defence of reasonable corporate precaution. This amendment relates to a situation where a company is vicariously liable for employees unless the company can establish that it took reasonable precautions and exercised due diligence to avoid the conduct of the employees. I do ask a question on this one. Is this an evidentiary onus requiring proof by the Crown to negative on the balance of probabilities that reasonable corporate precaution was taken, or is it a situation where the corporation must show—and, if so, to what degree is it on the balance of probabilities—that reasonable corporate precaution was taken? This is an area that I am not sure of and I ask the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice (Mr Williams) to clarify that.

The Witness Protection Act amendment is also, in my view, a good one and I do not think I need comment further. The consent to prosecute raises a couple of questions. Originally the acts under consideration required the consent of the minister if a person wished to institute a private prosecution. I suspect, although I do not know, that this was introduced following the amendment that was made in Queensland in the late 1970s, arising out of the famous case of Plunkett v. Bjelke‐Petersen.

That case was a private prosecution brought by a colleague, Mr Mark Plunkett, against Joh Bjelke‐Petersen in relation to the student bashing incident that occurred in Coronation Drive during one of the street marches. I suspect that that spawned a lot of legislation around the country in relation to frivolous and vexatious private prosecutions. I am not saying that that was a frivolous and vexatious prosecution but I am saying that that is probably where it started.

The question I have—very quickly; I apologise for taking as long as this—relates to this particular notion. In relation to consent by a minister to private prosecution, obviously political pressure can sometimes enter in. But does the amendment mean that, in relation to the offences where these acts are involved, no private prosecution can be brought? In other words, are people really relying on the Director of Public Prosecutions to exercise his or her discretion to commence a prosecution? If that is the case, that could be a matter that is not necessarily a good thing. I would be interested to hear the arguments in relation to that, because there is obviously greater political pressure that can be exercised on the minister than on the Director of Public Prosecutions.

This is a fairly complex and extensive series of amendments. In general I do not have a difficulty with them. I support the measures that have been introduced, save in so far as I have raised queries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating various policy and technical amendments to crime legislation. The Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 contains amendments to several acts.

SPEECH.PARA: As the proposed amendments are quite wide ranging, I wish to concentrate my speech today and tomorrow mainly on the amendment that relates to the Customs Act 1901 in which the Commonwealth will be able to recover costs associated with storage and maintenance of confiscated goods that are being used in conjunction with some form of drug trafficking.

Whilst other aspects of this legislation touch on the issue of sentences in relation to superannuation benefits in particular, I plan to speak specifically about sentencing in the context of the real need to impose harsher sentencing, most particularly for crimes associated with drug trafficking. As far as I am concerned, any legislation which addresses any issue of crime is highly important. I always take an interest in any legislation to do with crime and I welcome any opportunity to discuss this issue.

Unfortunately, within my electorate of Cowan, crime is a major problem creating concerns of fear and uncertainty within the community. The community of Cowan has been very active in addressing the issue and I have made representations on its behalf to local police and the commissioner concerning issues within the electorate. I would also like to point out that I actively support the neighbourhood watch programs and in this small way support the community in its fight against crime.

Although strictly a state issue, I believe that the issue of crime and crime rates has to be addressed as a whole community and addressed so that we can identify solutions for community safety, whether they be legislative, social policy or judicial. I believe the federal parliament has an important role to play in this whole process. Last year, for instance, the federal parliament acted quite properly in addressing the gun issue and I believe the broader community is safer, whether actually or in perception. They are in fact much safer in perception for the action that we took as a government, supported by the opposition.

Crime is a community issue and all forms of the community have a responsibility for seeking solutions. The amendment to the Customs Act 1901 which we debate today is a small step. It will mean the Commonwealth is able to recover expenses it incurs in relation to the transportation and storage of narcotic related goods that are condemned and placed in commercial storage facilities prior to the goods being transferred to the official trustee for disposal. Narcotic related goods are, as I understand it, various vehicles or materials that may be used in drug trafficking.

Today I would like to address some of the crime problems facing my electorate which it appears may be drug related and therefore impacted by this amendment. In my own electorate of Cowan, crime unfortunately is a major issue. It is a sad reality that many of the crimes committed can be related directly to drug problems.

BREAK.PARA: Only recently I received a letter from a constituent, saying that he heard gunfire within his particular suburb on an average of twice a week. Whether that precise summation is an actuality or not is quite inconsequential. My constituent was concerned and frightened enough to write to me and express a concern. This constituent, Mr Bell, a Vietnam veteran, wrote to me. I quote from his letter where he said:

We hear gunfire in this suburb on an average of twice a week (I have been on the receiving end of rifle fire enough times to know what it sounds like). These are some of your minority who like the thousands of others have escaped your tougher gun laws.

Mr Bell does have a point and I believe we must turn our thinking towards the penalties for drug traffickers, in getting tougher and getting angrier about the people who deal in drugs. That gunshots occur within a suburb at all is a disturbing reality. This government has, as I said before, already gone a long way towards addressing that problem but it is obvious that gun related problems will take time to properly clear up.

Members may be aware that the electorate of Cowan covers some of the northern suburbs of Perth. In these regions there are substantial levels of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, which can all too often result in bored or young individuals turning to drugs and drug related crime. I have some statistics regarding drug usage which I will speak about later. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 17 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What specific measures has the Government undertaken, or does it propose in law or in advice to the States and Territories, to reduce criminal avoidance from compliance with the new, standard, national gun laws.
(2) Is it a fact that under the development of standard national firearms laws, some States or Territories are proposing that firearms made before 1900 will not require any form of licensing.
(3) Is there a guideline or consensus on how collectors' weapons are to be rendered temporarily inoperative; if so, what are the details.
(4) Will prohibition of hand grenades for collectors apply to inert as well as live grenades.
(5) Is there a guideline for storage of weapons for gun owners who live in caravans or in remote settlements such as Aboriginal communities; if so, what are the details.

(6) What measures will the Commonwealth take to monitor the maintenance of common legislation which is consistent between the States and Territories once a standard national firearms legislative approach is achieved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the Australasian Police Ministers' Council (APMC) meeting on 10 May 1996, all State and Territory Police Ministers agreed that at the conclusion of the national compensation and amnesty scheme, each jurisdiction would have severe penalties for breaches for the firearms control laws. It was further agreed that, to the extent practicable, the penalties should be uniform.
At the national level, a public education campaign has commenced to persuade firearm owners to hand in prohibited firearms and to encourage compliance with the new firearms legislation.

(2) At its meeting of 17 July 1996, the APMC agreed that jurisdictions may consider not applying any requirement for licensing or registration of collection firearms manufactured before 1900, and for which cartridge ammunition is not commercially available. This is a matter for the individual State and Territory Governments to determine.

(3) The APMC agreed on 17 July 1996 that firearms manufactured after 1900 held in a collection must be rendered temporarily incapable of use by removal and separate secure storage of the bolt and/or firing pin or, if not feasible, by an appropriate trigger lock. Ministers further agreed that Category D firearms in a collection must be rendered permanently inoperable, and that jurisdictions may require Category C collection firearms to be rendered permanently inoperable.
(4) The APMC has not addressed requirements for hand grenade collections. This is a matter for-consideration by the individual State and Territory Governments.
(5) There is no specific guideline on this matter. On 10 May 1996, the APMC agreed upon the following minimum basic standards for the secure storage of firearms and ammunition:

PARA.TAB: Licence Category A and B: storage in a locked receptacle constructed of either hard wood or steel with a thickness to ensure it is not easily penetrable. If the weight is less than 150 kilograms the receptacle shall be fixed to the frame of the floor or wall so as to prevent easy removal. The locks fitted to these receptacles shall be of sturdy construction;
Licence Category C, D and H: storage in a locked, steel safe with a thickness to ensure it is not easily penetrable, bolted to the structure of a building; and
all ammunition must be stored in locked containers separate from any firearms.

ANSWER.PARA: The APMC further agreed that a firearms owner who wished to store firearms through other measures would have the burden of persuading the firearms regulatory authority that he or she can provide a level of security not less than that required by the relevant approved standard.

(6) The Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board ("the Board") has been involved in the development stages of the new firearms legislation in all States and Territories. The Board will continue to monitor the legislation to ensure that the APMC agreements are implemented and remain in place. As noted at the APMC meeting on 15 November 1996, the Australian Institute of Criminology has agreed to monitor and evaluate the new firearms controls. As part of this process, I have requested the Australian Institute of Criminology to prepare a detailed analysis of the State and Territory legislation.

There is no common legislation as such, nor is there a "standard national firearms legislative approach". It is up to each State and Territory Government to decide whether to incorporate the APMC agreements into existing legislation or to draft new legislation based upon the agreements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 19 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to comments reported in the Parkes Champion Post of 18 November 1996, made by Connell Wagner's Environmental Impact Statement Project Manager, Mr D. Brady, relating to the proposed Parkes airport initiative.

(2) Is he able to say whether the operation would grow from 2 aircraft each day to a 4 aircraft per day operation by 2010, based on a 1997 commencement with 50,000 tonnes of air freight and a 5% growth rate.
(3) Is he also able to say whether the operation would grow to a 10 to 15 aircraft per day operation, based on a 15% growth rate.
(4) Are the figures referred to in parts (2) and (3) sufficient to operate a profitable airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of the specific comments reported in the Parkes Champion Post of 18 November 1996. However, the Government has closely considered the Inland Marketing Corpo ration's (IMC) proposal for the establishment of an inland international air freight facility at Parkes.

(2)‐(4) The IMC has not provided any evidence of any intention by any international airline to operate services to Parkes. On the basis of current and projected freight flows and the economics of operating dedicated international freight aircraft, it is considered implausible that any international flights would operate to Parkes.
The IMC projections must be balanced against the reality of the airfreight market.

Currently there is approximately 9,400 tonnes per week of air freight capacity offered on outbound services from Australia. About 8,100 tonnes of this total (or 86 per cent) is operated in the belly holds of passenger aircraft. Of the nearly 700 scheduled international services per week to/from Australia, there are only 26 dedicated freighters operated and of these only 15 operate traffic rights (ie take on loads) out of Australia each week. The focus of operations of these dedicated freighters is to Sydney and Melbourne with Adelaide and Perth each receiving only one international freighter service per week.

Brisbane and Cairns are two rapidly growing international freight gateways. In the year ended 30 June 1996 Brisbane airport handled 34,753 tonnes of exports and 15,948 tonnes of imports while Cairns handled 6,636 tonnes of exports and 578 tonnes of imports. Despite this level of business and being in close proximity to some of the most productive agricultural production and export regions in Australia, neither airport can attract dedicated international freighter operations. The freight is carried in the belly holds on international passenger services. Accordingly, Parkes is unlikely to attract dedicated freight aircraft when these major airports, with established freight operations and infrastructure are unable to do so.

The Department of Transport has undertaken a detailed analysis of the IMC's throughput projections. The Department's analysis highlights that the IMC's export projections are based on attracting some 90% of the existing market of agricultural produce from NSW, Victoria and South Australia where its costs are competitive. This is considered extremely unlikely to be able to be realised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard , 2 December 1996, page 7256) concerning newsagents, has the Government lodged a submission with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) expressing a view that the present authorisations for home delivery should be retained for a fixed, four year period and no longer.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to any publishers intending to withdraw from existing distribution systems.
(3) Are third parties able to appeal any decision by the ACCC on this matter to the Australian Competition Tribunal.
(4) When did the Tribunal last consider this matter and what did it determine.
(5) Did he state in 1996 that he would permanently retain the present authorisations; if so, how.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 26 November 1996, the Government presented its submission to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (the ACCC) review of the authorisations for the newsagency distribution arrangements in New South Wales/the Australian Capital Territory, Queensland and Victoria.

The submission fulfils the Government's pre‐election commitment to support the home delivery system for newspapers. This system is currently authorised under competition law because the public benefits have been held to outweigh the anti‐competitive aspects of the system. The submission outlines the Government's views as to the benefits that derive from an efficient, low cost home delivery system for newspapers.

The submission proposes that the present authorisations be allowed to continue for another 4 years. After that time, it is envisaged that publishers and newsagents would be free to seek new authorisations, which would be assessed in light of any structural change which has occurred during that time. The submission acknowledges that the Government cannot direct the publishers on the distribution channels for their publications.
(2) No publishers are known to have expressed an intention to withdraw from existing distribution arrangements.

Advertiser Newspapers Ltd, publisher of the Advertiser in South Australia, has sought the ACCC's approval for revised distribution arrangements. However, the Advertiser has asked that a decision on the proposal be held in abeyance pending developments in the industry.

(3) Subsection 101(1) of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (along with Regulation 20 of the Trade Practices Regulations) provides that a person dissatisfied with a determination by the ACCC in relation to the revocation of an authorisation may, within 21 days of the date of the determination, apply to the Tribunal for a review of the determi nation. If the Tribunal is satisfied the person has a sufficient interest, the Tribunal shall review the determination.

(4) In November 1994 the Australian Competition Tribunal considered a determination of the Trade Practices Commission (now the ACCC) in relation to revised arrangements for the distribution of the publications of the Age and Herald and Weekly Times groups in Victoria. The determination of the Trades Practices Commission was made in 1993 following a fresh application for authorisation of a system designed to replace the then system, which was authorised by the Trade Practices Commission in 1982. The Tribunal set aside the 1993 determination of the Trade Practices Commission. As a result, the system authorised by the Trade Practices Commission in 1982 continued to operate. The findings of the Tribunal regarding the anti‐competitive effects and the public benefits of the system in that matter led the ACCC to commence a formal review of the authorisation for Victoria and, because of the similarity of arrangements, those for New South Wales/the Australian Capital Territory, Queensland and Victoria.
(5) See answer to question (1).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the (a) names and (b) populations of communities within lands for which title is held by the Haasts Bluff Land Trust.
(2) How many houses were constructed within those communities referred to in part (1) (a) prior to 1990 and (b) between 1990 and 1995 and (c) have been or are funded for construction since 1995.

(3) For the houses referred to in part (2), (a) what was the cost, (b) how was construction funded, (c) did the organisation or persons funded have secure title to the land upon which houses were constructed; if so, what form did it take; if not, who held secure title and what form did it take and (d) are rents charged; if so, (i) what sum is charged and how is it determined, (ii) who collects the rents, (iii) to whom is rent paid, (iv) how many houses have more than six weeks outstanding rent and (v) what is the sum and percentage of the collectable rents in each community that is outstanding.

(4) Did houses constructed after 1990 within those communities fail to satisfy established Northern Territory public housing standards; if so, (a) why were they constructed below the standards, (b) what was the cost and how was construction funded, (c) did the organisation or persons funded have secure title to the land upon which houses were constructed; if so, what form did it take; if not, who held secure title and what form did it take and (d) are rents charged; if so, (i) what sum is charged and how is it determined, (ii) who collects the rents, (iii) to whom is rent paid, (iv) how many houses have more than six weeks outstanding rent and (v) what is the sum and percentage of the collectable rents in each community that is outstanding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission with the following information in response to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Papunya approx 250 people
Areyonga approx 180 people
Haasts Bluff (Ikunji Community) approx 80 people
Mount Liebig (Amundurrngu Community) approx 300 people
Kintore (Walungurru Community) approx 350 people.

(2)(a) Detailed information on houses funded and constructed at the communities mentioned prior to 1990 would require considerable research. However data from the 1992 ATSIC Community Housing and Infrastructure Needs Survey shows the stock of houses in each Community as at mid 1992 as:
Papunya—21 houses and 17 shelters
Areyonga—31 houses
Haasts Bluff—10 houses
Mount Liebig—19 houses and 16 shelters
Kintore—42 houses and 6 shelters.
(3)(a) see above.

(b) In each case the standard ATSIC Grant procedure was followed. Funds were approved and Letters of Offer issued to the incorporated bodies representing the communities. Grantees appointed consultant project managers and public tenders were generally called.
(c) Title to the land in question is held by the Haasts Bluff Aboriginal Land Trust, granted as inalienable freehold title under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.
(d) Yes.

(i) Rental levels are determined by the community organisation in consultation with community members/tenants. The organisation is advised of the ATSIC guidelines on rental policy; which is that rents must be collected to a level which allows the Housing Organisation to pay rates and insurance, maintain the houses in a good state of repair and pay administrative expenses.
(ii) and (iii) Rents are collected by the funded organisation or their appointed agent.

(iv) and (v) ATSIC holds no information on the number of houses which have outstanding rents of more than six weeks or the sum or percentage of outstanding collectable rents in any of the listed communities.

(4) ATSIC advises that they have been advised that building standards in the NT are determined through the NT Building Act (1993) and its provi sions generally reflect those of the Building Code of Australia. Under this Act construction standards are applied to declared areas which are generally large towns. The communities in the Haasts Bluff Lands Trust area are not declared areas. Outside of declared areas agencies providing funds rely upon contractual arrangements to achieve housing standards. ATSIC requires grantee organisations to employ professionally qualified/registered contractors to undertake housing construction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many areas of land has the Haasts Bluff Land Trust been granted title to under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory Act).
(2) For the titles referred to in part (1), (a) when were they obtained, (b) what are the areas of land involved and (c) how were they obtained.

(3) What are the names of the persons or bodies who hold leases for areas of land from the Haasts Bluff Land Trust, and in each case (a) what is the area of land involved, (b) what is the purpose of the lease and (c) what are the terms and conditions of the lease.

(4) Do (a) traditional owners or (b) Aboriginal persons have security of tenure to reside on the lands; if so, is security of tenure absolute or qualified, and if it is qualified what are the qualifications; if not what must they do to obtain security of tenure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Haasts Bluff Aboriginal Land Trust has been granted one area of land under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

(2)(a) Former Governor General, Sir Zelman Cowan, granted title to the Trust to the area described in Schedule 1 of the Act, on 30 August 1978. The grant excluded from the area described in the schedule an area of 1.796 hectares being Lots 1, 2, and 3 Areyonga Townsite, Lots 2, 3 and 4 Papunya Townsite and Lot 3 Haasts Bluff Townsite. The grant also reserved to the Crown all rights to minerals in the area.

The Commonwealth Government subsequently amended the Act and this necessitated new deeds of grant to the Trust. Therefore, on 30 May 1980, the Governor General again granted the area to the Trust. However, the grant was effective from the date of the original grant. The new deed excluded certain roads from the land granted. These were firstly any land on which there was on the 26 January 1977 (when s.3 of the Act commenced) a road over which the public had, at that time, a right of way and secondly any land over which there was, at the time of the execution of the Deed of Grant, a road over which the public had a right of way.
On 29 October 1986, the Governor General, Sir Ninian Stephen, granted the townsites excluded from the initial grant to the Trust.

(b) The area is the land described in Schedule 1 to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 (copy of relevant part of schedule attached) and is Northern Territory Portion 1635. It is shown on Compiled Plan 4189 deposited with the Registrar General, Darwin.
(c) The area of land was obtained as a grant of Schedule 1 land under the Act.

(3) Insofar as most if not all the lease documents from the Trust have been registered against the title the appropriate method of obtaining the information is to apply to the Registrar General of the Northern Territory for a title search. It is not appropriate that I provide such information given that it would be commercial‐in‐confidence.

(4) Traditional owners have tenure provided for under the Act for Schedule 1 land. I do not consider it appropriate to provide legal advice in response to this question on notice. People who are concerned about the issues raised by the Honourable Member should seek their own legal advice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article on page 26 on the Sun‐Herald , dated 1 December 1996, entitled "Customs made bludger caught red handed".

(2) Is he able to provide details relating to the scam involving container loads of counterfeit cigarettes mentioned in the article; if so, (a) what were the names and addresses of the Chinese cigarette factories referred to, (b) who is the person with a Chinese diplomatic passport referred to as the head of the operation, (c) what companies are associated with that person and (d) what is the nature of the $40m worth of property assets associated with that person and those companies.

(3) Is he also able to provide details relating to alleged importation of 60 vehicles by a multi‐millionaire; if so (a) what sum of duty was avoided by the practices mentioned and (b) what are the names of the importers referred to in the article.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Customs, in co‐operation with several other Federal and State agencies and with the assistance of a number of cigarette manufacturing companies have been investigating allegations that counterfeit cigarettes have been illegally imported into Australia.

A number of containers have been examined as part of this work and there was one seizure in Sydney of 696,000 cigarettes (700 kgs) late last year where the cigarettes were concealed in a consignment of textiles. Prosecution action in respect of that consignment remains under consideration. There is no evidence establishing the involvement of any person holding a diplomatic passport.
It is inappropriate to make further comment at this time.

(3) Details of importations are provided to and held by the Australian Customs Service in confidence. I therefore regard it as inappropriate to reveal specific details of importers or their business transactions.
I have directed that the allegations made in the article be thoroughly investigated. Should there be any foundation to the allegations, appropriate action will be taken.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian War Memorial: Human Pathological Specimens

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the opinion of the Returned Services League of Australia formally canvassed before he approved the transfer of the Australian War Memorial's (AWM) collection of human pathological specimens to the NSW Institute for Forensic Science.
(2) Was there an AWM board resolution to transfer the collection; if so, when.
(3) On what terms has the collection been lent to the Institute.
(4) When was the collection transported to Sydney and on what date and by what means was it transported.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister's approval of the transfer of the material was not required under the Act. The National President of the Returned and Services League, Major General W B `Digger' James (also a medical doctor), was briefed on the issue during the year and inspected the material after its arrival in Sydney. He has endorsed the transfer and use of the collection by the NSW Institute of Forensic Medicine.
(2) This was not required.
(3) The loan is for a period of five years, subject to the following special conditions:

`At all times the material is to be treated with due sensitivity. The collection is to be used by the Institute for medical research and teaching relating to injuries sustained in warfare, and as such access to the collection is restricted to researchers. The collection is not available for access by the public without consent from the Memorial. Any conservation of the material will be carried out only in accordance with a treatment plan approved by the Memorial. Records of any such treatment are to be forwarded to the Memorial's Conservation department. The collection is only to be photographed for documentation or research purposes and copies of relevant photographs will be made available on request for the Memorial's records. Should there be any substantial organisational change which could affect the status of the Institute, and which might affect the material on loan, the Memorial is to be informed in writing and the loan may be reviewed by either party to the agreement'.
(4) On Monday 25 November 1996 the collection was transported in an air suspended, climate controlled Department of Administrative Services vehicle.
